17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

1912 Breakfast - porridge, bread & butter, or pancakes.
Dinner - potatoes (meat if we had it), beans, syrup and bread, tea.
Supper - potatoes, bread, tea.

Age:
1912, Mrs. Mawby 42, Margaret Mawby 14, Duncan Mawby 20 yrs, A.W. Mawby 15 yrs.

Winter months of 1912-1913.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

jumping deer meat, potatoes, gravy, pie.

Mrs. C.T. Mawby, 42 yrs, Margaret Mawby 14 yrs, Duncan Mawby 20 yrs, A.W. Mawby 15 yrs, Lorne Hainstock 26 yrs, Jack Hainstock 18 yrs, Irvine Campbell 20 yrs.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Never actually went hungry. But have had a good many meals of bread, potatoes, and a cup of tea.

19. **Were you ever refused to almost starvation level living on one or two local produced foods? Give details.**

   *Never actually went hungry. But have had a good many cups of tea, potatoes, and a cup of tea.*
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

In early days everything was done cooked and today we can buy it all cooked prepared and ready to cook.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

I have relied on purchased food since 1943.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

In our early days we bought food to last several months. Now we buy in smaller quantities for we have good roads now and stores are closer. Also our transportation is better. As for shortage of foods, that was only in wartime.
21. How did you begin to rely on purchased foods instead of home-prepared foods? (Give as many details as possible.)

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during the war.

In our early days we bought food to last several months. Now we buy in smaller quantities for we have good storage space and always are closer. Also our transportation is better than ever before.
